>> From the Library of
Congress in Washington, D.C.

6.text:

8.text:

writer and some illustrator.

19.text:

24.text:
Some Writer!: The Story
of E.B. White.

28.text:
Okay. Melissa has illustrated
nearly 100 children's books ranging

34.text:
from board books to
non-fiction titles.

38.text:
Born and raised in New
Jersey, Melissa graduated

41.text:

46.text:

51.text:

58.text:
Melissa has received many
honors for her illustrating

62.text:

Caldecott honors, a Sibert medal,

69.text:
the Orbis Pictus Award,
the Stieglitz Strauss award

78.text:
That's a lot of honors,
don't you think.

83.text:
Reviewers have described her
unique mixed media illustrations

88.text:
as creative delights
and I would agree.

92.text:
From her first job illustrating
the Pinky and Rex series

113.text:

but I'm 66 years old and think
this wonderful book will appeal

And so I listened to that for about

And the idea for this book

This one just popped

as I was looking for
next my biography.

I had done a few and I love

Life is always a rich and

235.text:
for something to happen or
to hatch, E.B. White said.

So the book begins

He wrote a chicken primer and of

in the doorway of the barn

258.text:
Immediately, questions came
up that had to be answered.

I wanted to know how did he come up

268.text:
How many drafts did it

272.text:
And living in Maine, I

How young was he when he

280.text:
And most importantly, what were

285.text:
So some of the dogs -- some of his

292.text:
We were totally different
kinds of kids but there --

296.text: we had a few things in common.

300.text:
someone asked him what dime novels
he read when he was growing up?

305.text:
And he said, never
read a dime novel.

307.text:
I spent my youth on a
bicycle and in trees.

312.text:
I spent my youth on
a bicycle with dogs.

315.text:
I loved to go to the library but I
was not a particularly great reader.

319.text:
Doesn't mean I didn't like books
but I didn't love reading as much

323.text:
as I did making art and playing

Who here had spirographs

So paint by numbers and color

336.text:
these things that looks like

342.text: So I was learning to make design.

I was kind of preparing

Anybody here grow up in the

349.text:
and have John Gnagy for -- a few
hands up there who taught us how

356.text:
And of course, I go to

360.text:
The artist Teresita
Fernandez said that --

363.text:
says that making art is a
solitary process and it is.

367.text:
So every day I go to my studio

376.text:
Early on in my career, I read that

381.text:
to her -- she wrote for 4

384.text:
if it's good enough for Joyce

387.text:
So my studio is part library,

392.text:
I have everything I need

and I do work probably
more than four hours.

400.text:
I don't do any of my

403.text:
It's all by hand and it's typical

409.text:
So I'm either writing a book

or I might be researching a book but

in my studio, I feel

420.text: So we'll move on from here.

423.text:
How do begin a biography of one
of America's most beloved writers?

428.text:
Well, I went back home after I had

I went to Cornell where

The family brought me
there and of course,

448.text:
you could see the title

450.text:
This book is revised and

And she was generous enough to

461.text:
I had done quite a bit of work

466.text:
And I had some preparation

469.text:
I had illustrated The Right

473.text: the man who invented the thesaurus.

476.text: He was a list maker as a kid.

478.text:
So in any biography, who are

484.text:

490.text:
I wrote and illustrated

Tony Sarg who invented the

And Horace Pippin who was a

506.text:
as a soldier in the war lost the
use of his right arm yet he went

513.text: So all these people had hardships

and difficulties along the

518.text:
And I think that is
such a riveting part

521.text:
of the research and
part of the story.

523.text:
And lastly, William Carlos Williams,
and I'll show you a little bit

528.text:
about how I break open

531.text:
So a lot of my books -- a lot

535.text:
And this is the spine of a

539.text:
The cover which I painted on and

And much of my work

545.text:
So the grid is what

548.text: Like a scaffolding or a skeleton.

551.text:
Design is not just
about making things.

554.text:
It's about making things happen
and this was absolutely a series

of teamwork between
Houghton Mifflin and myself.

561.text:
I do things -- give myself

563.text:
I made a family tree

566.text:
Why not? Just pull a tree out

570.text:
I had the pleasure of -- as

and I mapped the farm to give

576.text:
and also looking ways to tell the

583.text:
to say he went cross

585.text:
I can show where he went

589.text:
If there was one object,
though, I found was --

592.text:
represented E.B. White was
the essence of his work,

595.text:
it was the typewriter but do kids
know what a manual typewriter is?

599.text: We put directions at the beginning.

602.text:
And I used the manual typewriter

605.text:
This is an example of

611.text:
where there's a typewriter

614.text: And then at the bottom is a label.

616.text:
So also using office supplies like

620.text:
E.B. White wrote so many
essays and beautiful letters.

625.text: And as the research went on,

628.text:
I wanted to use those

631.text:
So I typed them up on a

635.text:
I consider these a

638.text:
My text goes along and then you come

643.text:
who he was a writer
and part of his life.

646.text:
Young scholars also want to know

650.text: and how do they get in the book?

And you'll see a little bit here

661.text: And I'm doing a lot of sketches.

And I'm trying to make that

And my husband said -- I wanted

And I said should I make

674.text: I don't know how to do this.

676.text:

679.text:
So I'm making all these pieces that

683.text:
And again you can see

685.text:
and I'm faking a book that's

688.text:
There are dozens of

691.text:
I've made but I've made Stuart

698.text:
I've made his bed made

703.text:
So just like when you're a

706.text:
and you're making all this stuff, I

710.text:
I'm just continuing to

So I think we don't have time to

723.text:
So that's the end -- the finished

729.text: He worked for The New Yorker.

733.text:
that he shared an office

737.text: And the two of them, James Thurber

739.text:
who would become a famous

Thurber was as gregarious

748.text:
And he also at The New
Yorker met his future wife,

753.text:
Katharine Angell was
a fiction editor.

755.text: They fell in love and married.

756.text:
She's also the mother
of Arthur Roger Angell.

759.text: One of the things I love most

764.text:
in E.B. White's writing
is The Elements of Style.

769.text:
That book came to him when
-- as when he was Cornell.

774.text:
We think of it now as Strunk and
White because years later, in the --

779.text:
later in his life, he
edited and revised it.

782.text:
So Elements of Style
became Strunk and White.

785.text:
Strunk and White's
Elements of Style.

788.text:
Katharine and E.B. White spent
the latter part of the years

792.text: at their farm in Maine and that's

795.text:
where he conceived the
story for Charlotte's Web.

798.text:
I'm not sure we're going to have
time to tell that whole story

800.text:
but in essence, there
was a sick pig.

805.text:
They tried their --
he tried his best

807.text: to save the pig's life but he died.

812.text:
I saw the pig was dead
and left him there.

815.text:
His face a mild look
expressive neither

817.text:
of deep peace nor deep suffering
although I think he had suffered a

823.text:
He buried the pig and
later said that I wanted

827.text: to find a way to save a pig's life.

830.text:
A while later he saw a
spider spinning a web

832.text: in the door yard of the barn.

835.text:
And he took that nest
-- sorry I said a web.

841.text: So she had laid her egg sack.

843.text: He took it back to New York.

847.text:
All these little spiders
were all over his dresser.

850.text:
He discovered that the
spiders were aranea cavtica

854.text:
and that he spent the next couple
of years researchign spiders.

861.text:
So he these two very
divergent episodes.

865.text:
Later, he was taken some slops
to the barn and he thought what

869.text: if a spider could save a pig's life.

871.text:
He wrote his editor,
Ursula Nordstrom,

873.text:
has there ever been a spider as a
main character in a children's book?

878.text:
Not as far as she knew
not since Ms. Muffett.

881.text:
[Chuckling] So the story of
Charlotte's Web was born.

887.text:
He was illustrated by Garth
Williams who struggled

890.text:
with anthropomorphizing Charlotte
and giving her a spider's face.

894.text:
E.B. White ended up accepting
the more scientific rendition

898.text:
of Charlotte and at the end, E.B.
White added three hairs and two eyes

905.text: to Charlotte and Charlotte was born.

912.text:
He started off I shall -- he
started off the book with Charlotte.

918.text:
Charlotte was a big, gray spider
living in the door yard of a barn

921.text:
but then he changed
to Wilbur, the pig.

924.text: I shall speak first of Wilbur.

926.text:
Another draft completely --
started completely with the barn

931.text: and all the animals in it.

932.text: And then he switched to the humans.

936.text:
John Arable went out to the
barn with a lit lantern.

942.text:
Finally setting the book aside, he
decided to start the book with Fern,

948.text:
the little girl, and he
-- it's the last line,

951.text:
this penultimate last line
was where's Papa going

957.text:
Editing it down to where's
Papa going with that axe?

960.text:
So I love showing these
five drafts in the book

963.text:
because it shows how he worked the
way many of us work with editing.

968.text:
He was a consummate
editor and reviser.

971.text:
He said Charlotte's Web is about
friendship, life, and death.

975.text:
Stuart Little was about
the quest for beauty.

981.text:
And Trumpet of the Swan was a
love story not just between Louie,

986.text:
the swan, and his wife, Serena,
but between father and son.

991.text:
So E.B. White's work is so
accessible and so delightful,

999.text:
I was such an honor
to create this book

1002.text:
that incorporated a
lot of his writings.

1009.text: We have time for one last quote.

1016.text:
White writes, sailors have an
expression about the weather.

1019.text:
They say the weather
is a great bluffer.

1022.text:
I guess the same can be
true of our human society.

1025.text:
Things could look dark
then a break shows

1030.text: in the cloud and all is changed.

1035.text:
It is quite obvious that the human
race has made a queer mess of life

1038.text:
on this planet but as a people, we
probably harbor seeds of goodness

1043.text:
that have lane waiting
for a long time.

1045.text:
Waiting to sprout when
the conditions are right.

1048.text:
Man's curiosity, his
relentless, his inventiveness,

1052.text:
his ingenuity have led
him into deep trouble.

1056.text:
We can only hope this same traits
will enable him to claw his way out.

1062.text:
Hang onto your hope for
tomorrow is another day.

1071.text: We might have time for one question.

1073.text:
We -- one or two questions
if anybody has any questions.

1078.text:
Maybe some of you met E.B.
White in your lifetime.

1088.text: What am I working on next?

I'm working on a picture book

Yes. Yes completely different

of writing and illustrating

1118.text:
>> This has been a presentation
of the Library of Congress.
